author: samwilsn
content:
I'm trying to think through how we could implement such functionality sanely.

So far my only idea for tooling would be to enforce that functions/classes/constants are consistently ordered between forks, so that the diffs make sense.

author: samwilsn
content: As long as each fork is maintained independently (maybe as different packages?) it should be doable.

author: pipermerriam
content: What about a two stage approach. For each fork pair A > B... Write the updated and new functionality alongside the previous fork rules. This iteration is focused on the simplest demonstration of the changes and is either released under the fork-A stable release line or as the fork-B beta/unstable release line. Then the changes get merged before entering into the  fork-B stable release line.

author: pipermerriam
content: This allows you to either view it as the minimal diff or standalone and the release versioning dictates how we keep such things organized.

author: pipermerriam
content: I like the idea of the minimal diff that shows the new rules being part of the Fork-A rules, and keeping the fork-B line clean of anything from the previous fork

author: pipermerriam
content: The part that sounds untenable is preserving the structure and function ordering. I'm not convinced this can be reliably enforced, or that diff tools will reliably give us something usable

author: pipermerriam
content: (I recognize I may be misinterpreting your plan/idea)

author: samwilsn
content: I don't think I follow. So you could either view the diff between `A -> B` but frozen at the first point where the `B` fork was initially written; or the latest version of `B`?

author: pipermerriam
content: Not perfect. Sort of awkward because the two views could go out of sync

author: samwilsn
content: I think I could whip something up using the `ast` module and some kind of `@since('berlin')` annotation to enforce ordering in a couple hours

author: pipermerriam
content: I think experimentation is going to be how this actually gets resolved. Good to maybe document the goals and measures different approaches that way

author: samwilsn
content: I think this would be extremely difficult if we have to patch specification errors in old forks, no?

author: samwilsn
content: Ideally I'd like to be able to run a command, and get two rendered documents: a plain version of `B`, and an annotated diff between `A -> B` that looks like the track changes option in word processors.
